title: Foundations of Business Management
content:
Module 1, Lesson 1: Foundations of Business Management

The Hook

Management is the discipline of getting things done through people. At its core, management is the process of planning, organising, leading, and controlling resources — human, financial, technological, and informational — to achieve organisational goals efficiently and effectively. Every business, government agency, non-profit, and even family operates through some form of management.

The study of management has evolved from the purely mechanistic scientific management of Frederick Taylor to today's humanistic, adaptive approaches that recognise people as the primary source of competitive advantage.

This lesson covers the four core management functions, leadership theory, organisational behaviour, strategic planning, and performance management — the five pillars that every effective manager must master.

The Concept

1. The Four Core Functions of Management

Planning defines objectives and selects strategies. Organising designs the structure for executing work. Leading motivates and directs people. Controlling monitors performance and takes corrective action.

2. Leadership Theory and Practice

Trait theory identifies characteristics of effective leaders. Situational Leadership (Hersey and Blanchard) adapts style to follower readiness. Transformational Leadership — inspiring followers to transcend self-interest for the collective good — is consistently associated with highest organisational performance.

3. Organisational Behaviour

Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory, and Vroom's Expectancy Theory explain motivation. Tuckman's team development model (Forming, Storming, Norming, Performing) guides team management.

4. Strategic Planning

PESTEL analysis examines the macro-environment. Porter's Five Forces analyses industry competition. SWOT analysis integrates internal and external factors. Porter's three generic strategies (Cost Leadership, Differentiation, Focus) guide competitive positioning.

5. Performance Management

The Balanced Scorecard measures performance across Financial, Customer, Internal Processes, and Learning perspectives. OKRs (Objectives and Key Results) provide a flexible goal-setting framework used by high-performing organisations.

The Illustration

Management is the practice of achieving goals through people and systems. In this lesson you have covered: the four management functions; leadership theory; organisational behaviour and motivation; strategic planning; and performance management frameworks. These foundations support every topic in this course.

Which leadership style involves involving team members in decision-making?

What is organisational behaviour?
options: The study of how buildings are organized
The study of how individuals and groups act within organizations
The process of restructuring a company

options: To avoid any changes in the organization
To guide and support employees through organizational transitions
